title: 112_s3205
content: The Act is titled the "Expatriation Prevention by Abolishing Tax-Related Incentives for Offshore Tenancy" or the "Ex-PATRIOT Act". It addresses the taxation of capital gains of nonresident alien expatriates. The Ex-PATRIOT Act amends section 871(a) of the Internal Revenue Code to impose a 30% tax on capital gains of nonresident alien individuals present in the US for 183 days or more, or specified expatriates, derived from sources within the US. The Ex-PATRIOT Act imposes a 30% tax on capital gains of nonresident alien individuals present in the US for 183 days or more, derived from US sources. Gains and losses from the sale of capital assets are taken into account only if they would be recognized if connected with a US trade or business, excluding certain provisions. For tax purposes, nonresident alien individuals or specified expatriates not engaged in US trade or business are treated as having a taxable year that is the calendar year. When determining gains or losses on assets held by specified expatriates subject to section 877A, the basis is considered to be the fair market value of the asset on the day before the expatriation date. For tax purposes, a specified expatriate is defined as a covered expatriate whose expatriation date occurs after 10 years prior to the enactment date. An individual can avoid being classified as a specified expatriate by proving to the Secretary that the loss of US citizenship was not intentional. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code states that an individual's US citizenship did not result in a significant tax reduction. The effective dates for the taxation and withholding amendments are specified. Former citizens who renounced citizenship to avoid taxation. Inadmissibility of Former Citizens under Section 212(a)(10)(E) of the Immigration and Nationality Act amended to include specified expatriates determined by the Secretary of the Treasury to be inadmissible. The term 'specified expatriate' is defined in section 871(a)(2)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary of the Treasury notifies the Secretary of State and others about excepted individuals. The Secretary of the Treasury notifies the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Homeland Security about individuals who are not specified expatriates under the Internal Revenue Code. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to prohibit waiver of inadmissibility. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for granting waivers to specified expatriates under the Internal Revenue Code. Individuals who meet tax status requirements may be granted a waiver of inadmissibility under the Immigration and Nationality Act if they incur a tax or penalty equal to the loss in tax revenue from losing US citizenship.
